body.value: George Bowering introduces BP Nichol and Lionel Kearns.
reading together night before at Carleton University
Annotation: Recording drops in volume, “looped” recording begins where another part of the reading can be heard in the background of the recording.
new collection to be released soon [perhaps The birth of God (Trigram Press, 1968) or Trips out (Western Press, 1968)
BP Nichol introduces unknown poem, first line “Out of the dark wood workings of the mind’s memories, we are alone...”.
BP Nichol reads unknown poem, first line “Out of the dark wood workings of the    mind’s memories, we are alone...”.
BP Nichol reads “Uneven Song”. *Note recording is looping over itself, so both BP and Lionel can be heard reading other poems in the background.
BP Nichol reads unknown poem, first line “Out of the middle the ends are taken...”.
from By the Light of the Silvery McLune: Media Parables
Gestures and other Assaults of the Interface (The Daylight Press, 1969)
BP Nichol introduces “Poem found among the ruins”.
BP Nichol reads “Poem found among the ruins”.
BP Nichol reads “Geners” [sp?] first line “Each human body a temple of the holy   ghost...”
BP Nichol reads “The True Eventual Story of Billy the Kid”.
published in a booklet The True Eventual Story of Billy the Kid (Weed/Flower, 1970)
and later    published in Craft Dinner: Stories & Texts 1966-1976 (Aya Press, 1978)
Lionel Kearns introduces “Expression”. [INDEX: from By the Light of the Silvery
BP Nichol introduces chant poem “umpa-pa beach park...”.
song “Over the white  cliffs of Dover” (perhaps Vera Lynn’s “There’ll Be Bluebirds Over The White Cliffs of Dover”)
BP Nichol sings sound poem “umpa-pa beach park...”.
Lionel Kearns reads “Insights”. [INDEX: from By the Light of the Silvery McLune:
translation of a poem by Antonio Machado
Unknown audience member asks question, but is CUT by the recording.
difficulty listening to long poetry readings
BP Nichol reads part of “Martyrology”, line “Days numbered as the years are even, time cannot withstand such order. St. Reat...”.
BP Nichol reads first line “Measure the clock, talk back time...”
BP Nichol introduces first line “Living now in terrible times, the TV talks from the
BP Nichol reads poem with first line “Living now in terrible times, the TV talks from the next room...”
Lionel Kearns introduces “The Woman Who” [INDEX: concrete poem, BP Nichol
CUT in tape, silence, from this point to 54:05.82 is actually from a part in the second half of the recording from 38:10.41 onwards.
Lionel Kearns begins to explain next poem, but there is a cut in the tape and the original recording continues.
Lionel Kearns introduces “Kinetic Poem”. [INDEX: from Pointing (Ryerson Press,
Lionel Kearns and BP Nichol read “Kinetic Poem”.
BP Nichol, Lionel Kearns and audience chant “Karnijikawa”.
Lionel Kearns introduces “The Parable of the Seventh Seal”.
Lionel Kearns answers question, continues to introduce “The Parable of the Seventh Seal”.
Lionel Kearns reads “The Parable of the Seventh Seal”.
